ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea

DT Article
TI New data about the Sinemurian and Lowermost Pliensbachian ammonites of
   the Central High-Atlas. Taxonomy and stratigraphical and
   paleobiogeographical implications.
FT Nouvelles donnees sur les ammonites du Sinemurien et du Pliensbachien
   basal du Haut Atlas central (Maroc). Taxonomie et implications
   stratigraphiques et paleobiogeographiques.
AU El Harriri, Khadija (hariri03@yahoo.fr) 
   Dommergues, Jean-Louis
   Meister, Christian
   Chafiki, Driss
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 29
IS 1
PS 217-260
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB A description of 25 taxa including a new species (Parasteroceras
   (Paroxynoticeras?) scaphitoides nov. sp.) in the area of Beni-Mellal,
   Midelt and Erachidia brings new information on the ammonite (2):
   465-469. stratigraphy and paleogeography of the Sinemurian and the base
   of the Pliensbachian in the Central High-Atlas. For that period seven
   stratigraphical units based on Tethyan taxa are distinguished. This
   Mediterranaen endemism appears at the genus level (Bouhamidoceras gr.
   zizense, Dudresnayiceras gr. suessiforme) but usually at species or
   subspecies level (Angulaticeras cf. coquandi, A. angustisulcatum,
   Arnioceras gr. rejectum, Asteroceras gr. varians, A. aff. langi,
   Parasteroceras (Paroxynoticeras) scaphitoides, Gleviceras richei,
   Microderoceras (Eoderoceras) gr. nothum-birchiaides). On the contrary
   Asteroceras gr. stellare, Paltechioceras gr. ardecrescens correspond to
   species with a wide geographical distribution.

   Marrakech, Morocco, Morocco.

AN ZOOR14709062997
DT Article
TI Anania, a new Cretaceous planktonic foraminiferal genus with meridional
   rugosity.
AU El-Nakhal, Hamed A. (hnakhal@yahoo.com) 
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 29
IS 2
PS 405-410
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Anania n. gen.. is introduced to include the Cretaceous planktonic
   foraminiferids that possess umbilical-extraumbilical primary aperture,
   supplementary sutural apertures on the umbilical side, inflated
   chambers, and meridionally arranged rugosity, which have been previously
   assigned to Ticinella and Hedbergella. Both Ticinella sp. cf. T. roberti
   (GANDOLFI), and Hedbergella costellata SAINT-MARC, of CARON (1978) which
   display meridional rugosity and supplementary sutural apertures, are
   treated as new species and formally named as Anania caronae, and A.
   shobairi, respectively. The definitions of Rugolobigerinacea and
   Abathomphalidae are emended, and the Ananiinae is introduced as a new
   subfamily to accommodate Anania n. gen.
C1 El-Nakhal, Hamed A.; POB 358, Gaza, Israel, Israel.
EM hnakhal@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 0253-6730

   Ocean; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Anania [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Anania caronae; Anania shobairi [South Atlantic /  / new species]
   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Ananiinae [Cretaceous /  / New subfamily]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea,
   Foraminiferida
OR Abathomphalidae - Pessagno 1967 (Foraminiferida): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   406; Fossil]. 
   Anania (Foraminiferida): [Gen nov, Of new subfamily Ananiinae, Type
   species Anania caronae, p. 406, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Anania caronae (Foraminiferida): [Sp nov, South Atlantic, Cretaceous, P.
   408; Fossil]. 
   Anania shobairi (Foraminiferida): [Sp nov, South Atlantic, Cretaceous,
   P. 408; Fossil].

   genus Anania, p. 406, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Rugoglobigerinacea - Subbotina 1959 (Foraminiferida): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 406; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Two new hypogean beetles from the Western Alps: Duvalius (Duvalius)
   lanai new species (Carabidae: Trechini) and Archeoboldoria sturanii new
   species (Cholevidae: Leptodirinae) (Coleoptera).
FT Due nuovi Coleotteri ipogei delle Alpi occidentali: Duvalius (Duvalius)
   lanai n. sp. (Carabidae: Trechini) e Archeoboldoria sturanii n. sp.
   (Cholevidae: Leptodirinae) (Coleoptera).
AU Casale, Achille (casale@uniss.it) 
   Giachino, Pier Mauro
SO Rivista Piemontese di Storia Naturale
VL 31
PS 213-240
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Duvalius (Duvalius) lanai new species is described from two caves in the
   Ligurian Alps: Grotta del Rospo cave and Pozzo Congiuntivite cave near
   Montaldo di Mondovi (S. Anna Collarea, Cuneo province). Close to D. (D.)
   carantii (Sella, 1874), the new species is markedly distinct for the
   larger size, the more rounded elytral shoulders, the fully vanished
   traces of the eyes, the different shape of both median lobe of aedeagus
   and copulatory piece. With the sympatric species D. morisii, it
   represents the Easternmost representative of the D. carantii species
   group, that includes some taxa spread in Ligurian and Maritime Alps.
   Archeoboldoria sturanii new species is described from the Buca del
   Ghiaccio cave (Monte Cavallaria, Brosso, Torino province). The new taxon
   is the first representative in the Grajan Alps of a genus previously
   known only from the Pennine Alps, and seems to be closely related to A.
   doderona (Jeannel, 1924), a species spread in the mountains of the area
   Biellese-Monte Rosa, on the opposite side of the Dora Baltea valley.
   From the latter, it is distinguishable for some marked differences both
   in external features and in the structure of male genitalia.
   Furthermore, some biogeographic notes are also given concerning the
   peculiar distributions of both taxa described in the present paper.
C1 Casale, Achille; Univ Sassari, Dipartimento Zool & Genet Evoluzionist,
   Via Muroni 25, 07100 Sassari, Italy, Italy.
EM casale@uniss.it

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   /  / New record; systematics] [Italy /  / biology; distribution; natural
   history]. 
   Archeoboldoria sturanii; Duvalius (Duvalius) lanai [Italy /  / New
   species].

PT J
AN ZOOR14610065891
DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS Pseudocalotes (SQUAMATA: AGAMIDAE) FROM
   VIETNAM.
AU Hallermann, Jakob (hallermann@uni-hamburg.de) 
   Nguyen Quang Truong
   Orlov, Nikolai
   Ananjeva, Natalia
SO Russian Journal of Herpetology
VL 17
IS 1
PS 31-40
PD January-March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Members of the genus Pseudocalotes of the Indochinese region were
   reviewed and a new species from Kon Tum province, Central Vietnam is
   described The new species is similar in appearance to P. brevipes and P.
   floweri but it is distinguished from these species by the combination of
   the following characters body scale shape, subdigital scale form, and
   coloration. Distribution patterns of the species P. brevipes,
   microlepis, floweri, and poilani, including all available new material
   of these species are discussed An identification key to the species of
   the genus is provided.
C1 Hallermann, Jakob; Univ Hamburg, Zool Museum, Martin Luther King Pl 3,
   Hamburg, Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI Devibursaphelenchus wangi sp. n. (Nematoda: Ektaphelenchinae) feeding on
   Aphelenchoides sp.
AU Gu, Jianfeng (gujf@nbciq.gov.cn) 
   Wang, Jiangling
   Zheng, Jingwu
SO Russian Journal of Nematology
VL 18
IS 1
PS 49-57
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Devibursaphelenchus wangi sp. n. is described and figured. The new
   species was isolated from pine packaging wood from the USA and inspected
   in Ningbo harbour, China in 2009. The new species is characterised by
   relatively slender body (a = 36.5 and 37.1 for males and females,
   respectively); three lines in the lateral field; stylet with relatively
   wide lumen but lacking basal knobs; vulval flap absent, very short
   post-uterine sac; non-functional and indistinct female rectum and anus;
   spicules relatively small (14.2-15.6 [mu]m) with a flattened cucullus;
   two pairs of caudal papillae. The new species is morphologically close
   to D. eproctatus and D. hunanensis and can be distinguished by shape and
   size of spicules and smaller stylet. The separate species status is
   supported by ITS-RFLP patterns and molecular phylogenetic analysis based
   on ITS 1/2 and partial LSU sequences, which revealed that the new
   species is close to D. hunanensis. The feeding habit of the new species
   is also observed and discussed.
C1 Gu, Jianfeng; Zhejiang Univ, Inst Biotechnol, Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China,
   China.
EM gujf@nbciq.gov.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0869-6918
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; North America
DE Devibursaphelenchus wangi [Zhejiang /  / New species] [USA /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Devibursaphelenchus wangi (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Zhejiang, P. 50].

DT Article
TI Description of Bursaphelenchus braaschae sp n. (Nematoda:
   Aphelenchoididae) found in dunnage from Thailand.
AU Gu, Jianfeng (gujf@nbciq.gov.cn) 
   Wang, Jiangling
SO Russian Journal of Nematology
VL 18
IS 1
PS 59-68
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB Bursaphelenchus braaschae sp. n. is described and figured. The new
   species was isolated from deciduous dunnage from Thailand. The new
   species belongs to the fungivorus group of the genus. It is
   characterised by relatively stout body (a = 23.5 and 24.0 for males and
   females, respectively); four lines in the lateral field; spicules
   relatively small and delicate (14.2-16.3 [mu]m) with blunt rostrum and
   rounded distal end without cucullus, condylus thin and high, not
   dorsally bent, dorsal edge of spicules along condylus with
   characteristic darker section; and by females with strongly protruding
   vulva lips and a slim, attenuated tail with rounded terminus. The new
   species is morphologically closest to B. willibaldi and can be
   distinguished by the shape and size of spicules, post-uterine sac length
   and vulva position. The new species status is supported by ITS-RFLP
   patterns and molecular phylogenetic analysis based on partial SSU, ITS
   1/2 and partial LSU sequences, which revealed that B. braaschae sp. n.
   is closest to B. willibaldi.
C1 Gu, Jianfeng; Ningbo Entry Exit Inspect & Quarantine Bur, Ctr Tech, 9
   Mayuan Rd, Ningbo, Zhejiang, China, China.
EM gujf@nbciq.gov.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0869-6918
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Bursaphelenchus braaschae [Zhejiang /  / New species] [Thailand /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda

DT Article
TI Studies on the genus Aporcelaimellus Heyns, 1965 (Dorylaimida:
   Aporcelaimidae) - material studied by Thorne and Swanger in 1936 but not
   named.
AU Alvarez-Ortega, Sergio (saortega@ujaen.es) 
   Pena-Santiago, Reyes
SO Russian Journal of Nematology
VL 18
IS 1
PS 69-84
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The identity of four species of Aporcelaimellus sensu lato studied, but
   not originally described, by Thorne and Swanger in 1936 are analysed and
   discussed on the basis of studies on the material deposited in Thorne's
   collection. Dorylaimus papillatus is described and illustrated, and
   provisionally considered to be a valid species since it is
   distinguishable from A. obtusicaudatus by the vagina, which is without
   pars refringens. The material labelled as Dorylaimus perfectus, often
   regarded as a synonym of A. obtusicaudatus, consists of two males very
   similar to those described for Labronema goodeyi, and seven females
   certainly belonging to A. obtusicaudatus; measurements and illustrations
   of these specimens are provided. One male labelled as Dorylaimus
   paraobtusicaudatus is Metaporcelaimus romanicus; it is described in
   detail and illustrated. Part of the material originally described as
   Dorylaimus propinquus is actually Aporcelaimellus waenga, of which new
   data, including detailed description, measurements and illustrations,
   are provided; in addition, Aporcelaimellus laevis is regarded as a
   junior synonym of A. waenga.
C1 Alvarez-Ortega, Sergio; Univ Jaen, Dept Biol Anim Biol Vegetal & Ecol,
   Campus Las Lagunillas S-N,Edificio B3, Jaen, Spain, Spain.
EM saortega@ujaen.es
RI Alvarez-Ortega, Sergio/C-2064-2016; PENA-SANTIAGO, Reyes/K-2713-2019
OI Alvarez-Ortega, Sergio/0000-0003-2077-5041; Pena Santiago,
   Reyes/0000-0003-1125-5490
SC Zoology
SN 0869-6918
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Aporcelaimellus - Heyns 1965 (Nematoda): [Systematics, Material studied
   by Horne & Swanger in 1936 but not named, p. 69]. 
   Aporcelaimellus waenga - (Yeates 1967) (Nematoda): [Syn nov,
   Aporcelaimellus laevis Tjepkema, Ferris & Ferris 1971, p. 81]. 
   Dorylaimida (Nematoda): [Systematics, Material studied by Horne &
   Swanger in 1936 but not named, p. 69]. 
   Dorylaimus domus glauci - Cobb 1893 (Nematoda): [Taxonomic position,
   Species incertae sedis, p. 72]. 
   Dorylaimus papillatus - Bastian 1865 (Nematoda): [Status, P. 71].

AN ZOOR14705041505
DT Article
TI A new stem nematode, Ditylenchus weischeri sp. n. (Nematoda:
   Tylenchida), a parasite of Cirsium arvense (L.) Scop. in the Central
   Region of the Non-Chernozem Zone of Russia.
AU Chizhov, Vladimir N. (chizhov@list.ru) 
   Borisov, Boris A.
   Subbotin, Sergei A.
SO Russian Journal of Nematology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 95-102
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 21
AB A new species of the stem nematode, Ditylenchus weischeri sp. n.
   parasitising creeping thistle, Cirsium arvense (Asteraceae), is
   described from material collected in the Moscow region, Russia.
   Ditylenchus weischeri sp. n. differs from D. dipsaci by shorter tails in
   adults, larger c index, shorter spicules, longer vulva-anus distance,
   larger vulva-anus distance to tail length ratio and longer posterior
   sac. Ditylenchus weischeri sp. n. differs from other Ditylenchus in
   ITS-rRNA and hsp90 gene sequences and chromosome numbers. Ditylenchus
   weischeri sp. n. did not develop and complete its life cycle in onion
   and garden strawberry seedlings, which are typical hosts for D. dipsaci.
   Diagnostic PCR-ITS-RFLP profiles are given for D. weischeri sp. n. and
   D. dipsaci.
C1 Chizhov, Vladimir N.; Russian Acad Sci, AN Severtsov Inst Ecol & Evolut,
   Leninskii Prospect 33, Moscow, Russia, Russia.
EM chizhov@list.ru
RI Chizhov, Vladimir/J-3591-2018
OI Chizhov, Vladimir/0000-0002-9561-3103

SN 0869-6918

   disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   species] [Russia /  / New species from plant host]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Ditylenchus dispaci (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters, P. 97]. 
   Ditylenchus weischeri (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Russia, Parasite of Cirsium
   arvense (Plant), p. 99; Parasite].

DT Article
TI Two new species of free-living nematodes from Lake Baikal, Russia.
AU Gagarin, Vladimir G. (gagarin@ibiw.yaroslavl.ru) 
   Naumova, Tatyana V.
SO Russian Journal of Nematology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 103-110
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Monhystera melnikae sp.n. and Boreolaimus communis sp.n. were described
   from Lake Baikal (Russia, Siberia). Monhystera melnikae sp. n. is
   similar to M. lemani Juget, 1969 and M. amabilis Gagarin, 1997, but
   differs from M lemani by having the longer tail, a different position of
   vulva, more posteriorly placed amphidial fovea and shorter spicules.
   From M. amabilis it differs by having a shorter body, the wider labial
   region, shorter outer labial setae and more posteriorly placed amphidial
   fovea. Boreolaimus communis sp.n. resembles B. septemtrionalis Andrassy,
   1998 but differs by having a shorter tail, the shorter odontostyle,
   absence of 'saccate bodies' at the postanal region in females and
   presence of males.
C1 Gagarin, Vladimir G.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Biol Inland Waters, Borok,
   Yaroslavl Region, Russia, Russia.

   V/B-5887-2018

   Eurasia

   Boreolaimus communis; Monhystera melnikae [Russia /  / New species].

DT Article
TI Morphological and molecular characterisation of Longidorus tabrizicus sp
   n. and L. sturhani Rubtsova, Subbotin, Brown and Moens, 2001 (Nematoda:
   Longidoridae) from north-western Iran.
AU Niknam, Gholamreza (g_niknam@tabrizu.ac.ir) 
   Pedram, Majid
   Nejad, Elmira Ghahremani
   Ye, Weimin
   Robbins, Robert T.
   Maafi, Zahra Tanha
SO Russian Journal of Nematology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 127-140
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Longidorus tabrizicus sp. n., an amphimictic species is described based
   on two populations recovered from soil samples collected from the
   rhizosphere of apple trees in Namin, Ardebil province and the
   rhizosphere of Rosa sp. from Maragheh, East Azarbaijan province, Iran in
   a population mixed with L. sturhani. The new species is characterised by
   having anteriorly flattened lip region separated from the rest of the
   body by a shallow depression, medium body length (4.2-6.1 mm),
   pocket-shaped amphidial pouches without distinct basal lobes, short
   odontostyle (61.5-69.0 [mu]m) and odontophore (43.0-54.0), a bluntly
   conoid tail, three juvenile stages and males common equal in number to
   females. The new species most closely resembles 11 known species, namely
   L. moniloides, L. globulicauda, L. ampullatus, L. auratus, L. makatinus,
   L. kakamus, L. rotundicaudatus, L. pini, L. sylphus, L. bernardi and L.
   sturhani. Phylogenetic trees based on sequences of the 18S and ITS1 rDNA
   regions representing the relationships of L. tabrizicus n. sp. and all
   other species of Longidorus Micoletzky, 1922 with available sequences of
   the same regions are presented. Longidorus sturhani is the closest to
   the new species regarding both morphological and molecular characters.
   The Iranian population of L. sturhani is similar to the European
   populations (according to original description) but has a wider diameter
   at mid-body and smaller a ratio.
C1 Niknam, Gholamreza; Univ Tabriz, Fac Agr, Tabriz, Iran, Iran.
EM g_niknam@tabrizu.ac.ir
RI Tanha Maafi, Zahra/S-2888-2016
SC Zoology
SN 0869-6918
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Longidorus tabrizicus [Iran /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Longidorus sturhani (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters, P. 136]. 
   Longidorus tabrizicus (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Iran, P. 128].

DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14705041512
DT Article
TI Three new free-living nematode species (Nematoda, Enoplida) from
   mangrove habitats of Nha Trang, Central Vietnam.
AU Tchesunov, Alexei V. (AVTchesunov@yandex.ru) 
   Mokievsky, Vadim O.
   Nguyen Vu Thanh
SO Russian Journal of Nematology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 155-173
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Three new nematode species of the order Enoplida were found in a
   degrading mangrove biotope in the Bay of Nha Trang, Central Vietnam.
   Admirandus belogurovi sp. n. (Oncholaimidae), a second species of the
   genus, differs from the only other species, A. multicavus Belogurov et
   Belogurova, 1979, in having shorter spicules (41-49 vs 71-110 [mu]m) and
   some measurements, as well as presence of a small midventral preanal
   supplementary papilla. Diagnosis of the genus Admirandus Belogurov et
   Belogurova, 1979 is emended. Tripyloides caudaensis sp. n.
   (Tripyloididae) is close to a group of species T. gracilis (Ditlevsen,
   1918), T marinus (Butschli, 1874) and T pallidus Tchesunov, 1981 with
   partly overlapped measurements and differs from them in shape of the
   tail consisting of distinct proximal conical and distal slender
   cylindrical portions and from T pallidus additionally by oviparity vs
   viviparity. An annotated list of eleven valid species and a pictorial
   key for identification of Tripylodes species are given. Litinium
   subterraneum sp. n. (Oxystominidae) is characterised by the position of
   the amphideal fovea closely behind the circle of twelve anterior setae
   and presence of two preanal supplementary papillae. Litinium
   subterraneum sp. n. differs from the related L. aequale Cobb, 1920,
   Litinium sp. 1 and Litinium sp. 2 (both latter unnamed species were
   found in mangroves of Vietnam, Quang Ngo Xuan et al., 2008) in body
   length, relatively longer tail, position of the amphideal fovea,
   relative pharynx length, different distance from the cephalic apex to
   the ventral pore. Some data on microscale distribution of three species
   in mangrove intertidal zone are provided.
C1 Tchesunov, Alexei V.; Moscow State Univ, Fac Biol, Moscow, Russia,
   Russia.
EM AVTchesunov@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0869-6918
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Documentation;
   Publications; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Admirandus belogurovi; Litinium subterraneum; Tripyloides caudaensis
   [North Pacific / Vietnam / New species]. 
   Tripyloides [Checklists /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Admirandus - Belogurov & Belogurova 1979 (Nematoda): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 157]. 
   Admirandus belogurovi (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Vietnam (marine), P. 160]. 
   Litinium subterraneum (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Vietnam (marine), P. 168]. 
   Tripyloides - de Man 1886 (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 162]. 
   Tripyloides caudaensis (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Vietnam (marine), P. 165].

DT Article
TI Steinernema schliemanni sp n. (Steinernematidae; Rhabditida) - a new
   species of steinernematids of the 'monticolum' group from Europe.
AU Spiridonov, Sergei E. (s_e_spiridonov@rambler.ru) 
   Waeyenberge, Lieven
   Moens, Maurice
SO Russian Journal of Nematology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 175-190
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Steinernema schliemanni sp. n. found on the surface of a cadaver of
   Osmoderma ceremita (Coleoptera) in Germany in April 2003 is described.
   The new species belongs to the group of species related to S. monticolum
   ('monticolum'-group). It differs from the other species of this group in
   the structure of the lateral field of infective juveniles, viz. 8 equal
   ridges at mid-body in S. schliemanni sp. n. vs unequal ridges in S.
   monticolum and S. robustispiculum and five ridges in S. ashiuense.
   Infective juveniles of S. schliemanni sp. n. are longer (842-1008 [mu]m)
   than those of all other species of the 'monticolum' group. Steinernema
   schliemanni sp. n. differs from the other species of the
   'monticolum'-group in at least 115 positions of the ITS rDNA sequence
   (18%). The nucleotide difference of the D2D3 region of the LSU rDNA
   between S. schliemanni sp. n. and the closest species, S. monticolum, is
   22 bp (3.9% of the compared sequences), which is higher than differences
   between species such as S. feltiae, S. kraussei and S. oregonense. The
   16S rDNA sequence of the bacterium associated with S. schliemanni sp. n.
   demonstrates close relationships with several Xenorhabdus species; the
   nucleotide difference is the lowest with X hominickii (28 bp or 2%),
   isolated from S. monticolum.
C1 Spiridonov, Sergei E.; Russian Acad Sci, AN Severtsov Inst Ecol &
   Evolut, Leninskii Prospect 33, Moscow, Russia, Russia.
EM s_e_spiridonov@rambler.ru
RI Spiridonov, Sergei E./A-5383-2016
OI Spiridonov, Sergei E./0000-0001-6657-0418
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0869-6918
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Galleria mellonella [Nematode parasites / Steinernema schliemanni / New
   parasite species]. 
   Osmoderma [Nematode parasites / Steinernema schliemanni / New parasite
   species] [Germany /  / New nematode parasite species]. 
   Steinernema schliemanni [Coleopteran hosts / Osmoderma / New parasite
   species] [Lepidopteran hosts / Galleria mellonella / ] [Germany /  / New
   species from coleopteran host]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans; Nematodes

   Galleria mellonella (Pyralidae): [Host]. 
   Steinernema schliemanni (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Germany, Parasite of
   Osmoderma (Coleoptera), p. 180; Parasite].

DT Article
TI Enchodelus decraemerae sp. n. and Enchodorus dolichurus Vinciguerra,
   1976 (Dorylaimida: Nordiidae), two rare species from Iran.
AU Pourjam, Ebrahim (pourjame@modares.ac.ir) 
   Pedram, Majid
   Vinciguerra, Maria T.
   Robbins, Robert T.
SO Russian Journal of Nematology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 191-197
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of Enchodelus is described in this study. It belongs to
   the group of species with very long odontostyle (61-67 [mu]m) and
   conical tail and is also characterised by having a 1.49-1.72 mm long
   body, 25-36 [mu]m long tail and presence of abundant males in the
   population with 45-52 [mu]m long spicules and 10-12 irregularly spaced
   ventromedian copulatory supplements. The new species is compared with E.
   maximus Bawl and Jairajpuri, 1974 and E. nepalensis Zullini, 1973, from
   which it differs from E. maximus by its shorter body (1.49-1.72 vs
   2.48-2.60 mm), smaller a value (23.0-30.5 vs 41-45), longer odontostyle
   (61-67 vs 54-57 [mu]m), posteriorly located guiding ring (45-51 vs 35-36
   [mu]m from anterior end), much shorter female tail (c' 0.9-1.3 vs about
   2) and having functional males in population vs absence of males. It
   also can be differentiated from E. nepalensis by having shorter body
   (1.49-1.72 vs 2.1-2.3 mm), smaller b value (5.0-5.7 vs 6.4-6.5), shorter
   female tail (c' 0.9-1.3 vs 1.7) and by having 10-12 ventromedian
   copulatory supplements vs 5. Enchodorus dolichurus Vinciguerra, 1976, a
   rare species of a rare genus, found so far only in Italy, is also
   redescribed and illustrated for the first time from Iran.
C1 Pourjam, Ebrahim; Univ Tarbiat Modares, Dept Plant Pathol, Tehran, Iran,
   Iran.
EM pourjame@modares.ac.ir
SC Zoology
SN 0869-6918
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Enchodelus decraemerae [Iran /  / New species]. 
   Enchodorus dolichurus [Iran /  / New record; systematics]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Enchodelus decraemerae (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Iran, P. 192]. 
   Enchodorus dolichurus - Vinciguerra 1976 (Nematoda): [Redescription, P.
   196; New record].

AN ZOOR14706047341
DT Article
TI Bryozoa from the Langhian (Miocene) of the Czech republic part i:
   Geology of the studied sections, systematic description of the orders
   Cyclostomata, Ctenostomata and 'anascan' Cheilostomata (suborders
   Malacostega Levinsen, 1902 and Flustrina Smitt, 1868).
AU Zagorsek, Kamil (kamil_zagorsek@nm.cz) 
SO Sbornik Narodniho Muzea v Praze Rada B Prirodni Vedy
VL 66
IS 1-2
PS 3-136
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A total of 158 species of Bryozoa have been found and indentified in
   sediments from 34 sections, all of Langhian (Early Badenian) age, from
   the Czech Republic. All the studied sections where bryozoans were found
   have been described. All identified species belonging to the orders
   Cyclostomata. Ctenostomata and "Anascan" Cheilostomata (Suborders
   Malacostega Levinsen, 1902 and Flustrina Smitt, 1868) are described and
   illustared in detail. Among them are four new species: Frondipora parva
   sp.n., Copidozown natalae sp. n., Cupuladria baluki sp.n. and Calpensia
   rebeshovensis sp.n.

TI Bryozoa from the Langhian (Miocene) of the Czech republic part II:
   Systematic description of the suborder Ascophora Levinsen, 1909 and
   paleoecological reconstruction of the studied paleoenvironment.
AU Zagorsek, Kamil (kamil_zagorsek@nm.cz) 
SO Sbornik Narodniho Muzea v Praze Rada B Prirodni Vedy
VL 66
IS 3-4
PS 139-255
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A total of 158 species of Bryozoa were found and indentified from the
   sediments of 34 sections, all of Langhian (Early Badenian) age, from the
   Czech Republic. Bryozoan species belonging to the suborder Ascophora
   LEVINSEN, 1909 are described in detail and illustrated. Among them are
   12 new species Umbonula granulata sp. n., Ferganula rousinovensis sp.
   n.. Microporella berningi sp. n. Cribellopora hluchovensis sp. n..
   Cribellopora trasoni sp. n., Buffonellaria kuklinskii sp. n..
   Buffonellaria holubicensis sp. n.. Reteporella hluchovensis sp. n.,
   Reteposella vladkae sp. n., Reteporella ruzenkae sp. n. Rhyachozoon
   oslavanensis sp. n.. Rhynchozoon krouzkovensis sp. n. The type of
   environment which may have lead to the mass occurrence of Bryozoa is
   proposed.

DT Article
TI Three new genera of Electridae (Bryozoa): Arbopercula, Osburnea, and
   Arbocuspis.
AU Nikulina, E.A. (en@gpi.uni-kiel.de) 
SO Schriften des Naturwissenschaftlichen Vereins fuer Schleswig-Holstein
VL 72
PS 25-28
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three groups of cheilostome bryozoan species, formerly classified in the
   genus Electra Lamouroux, and possessing branching spines [long dash] the
   feature strictly discriminating them from all other electrids, are
   placed in three new genera based on unique combinations of features of
   spines, cryptocysts, and opercula: Osburnea gen. nov. is established for
   the Electa biscuta Osburn; Arbocuspis gen. nov. for Electra bellula
   (Hincks), and Arbopercula gen. nov. for Electra bengalensis (Stolizcka).

DT Article
TI Late Carboniferous (Moscovian) choristitid brachiopods from Nagaiwa in
   the South Kitakami Belt, NE Japan.
AU Tazawa, Jun-ichi
SO Science Reports of Niigata University Geology
VL 25
PS 1-16
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study describes the following four choristitid brachiopod species
   from the Upper Carboniferous (Moscovian) Nagaiwa Formation of Nagaiwa,
   South Kitakami Belt, northeast Japan: Choristites mosquensis Fischer de
   Waldheim, Choristites jigulensis (Stuckenberg), Parachoristites
   nagaiwensis sp. nov., and Parachoristites sp. The occurrence of these
   brachiopods suggests that the South Kitakami region was part of the
   continental shelf bordering the eastern margin of North China
   (Sino-Korea) during the Late Carboniferous. This finding supports the
   strike-slip model, one of three models proposed to explain the
   Pre-Neogene tectonics of Japan.
C1 Tazawa, Jun-ichi; Department of Geology, Faculty of Science, Niigata
   University, Niigata 950-2181, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 1349-1237
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Choristitidae [Japan / Honshu, Iwate, Nagaiwa / systematics]
   [Carboniferous / Moscovian / ]. 
   Parachoristites nagaiwensis [Japan /  / new species] [Carboniferous /  /
   ]. 
TN Brachiopods; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Brachiopoda
OR Choristitidae - Waterhouse 1968 (Brachiopoda): [Fossil]. 
   Parachoristites nagaiwensis (Brachiopoda): [Sp nov, Japan,
   Carboniferous, P. 9; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Donetzites miyakei, a new species of Early Carboniferous tabulate coral
   from the Omi Limestone, Niigata Prefecture, central Japan.
AU Ibaraki, Yousuke
   Niko, Shuji
   Tazawa, Jun-ichi
SO Science Reports of Niigata University Geology
VL 25
PS 29-34
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of cleistoporid tabulate coral, Donetzites miyakei, is
   described from the Endothyra Zone (late Visean, Early Carboniferous) of
   the Omi Limestone at the Nishiyama quarry in the Omi area, Niigata
   Prefecture, central Japan. It represents the earliest Donetzites
   recorded so far. Stratigraphic and geographic distributions of
   Donetzites may be explained as the result of westward spread reaching
   into the Tethys from it possible origin in the central Panthalassa.
   Comparable taxon with D. miyakei is D. vermiculatus Niko, 1999 from the
   Eostaffella- Millerella Zone of the Hina Limestone, Okayama Prefecture,
   southwest Japan.
C1 Niko, Shuji; Department of Environmental Studies, Faculty of Integrated
   Arts and Sciences, Hiroshima University, Hiroshima 739-8521, Japan,
   Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 1349-1237

   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Tabulata

DT Article
TI Middle Permian brachiopods from Yamasuge in the Kuzu area, Ashio
   Mountains, central Japan.
AU Tazawa, Jun-ichi
   Okumura, Yohoko
   Kojima, Hideo
SO Science Reports of Niigata University Geology
VL 25
PS 35-49
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A Middle Permian brachiopod fauna consisting of seven species in six
   genera is described from the lower part of the Nabeyama Formation
   (Parafusulina yabei Zone, Murgabian or Wordian) of Yamasuge in the Kuzu
   area, Ashio Mountains, central Japan. New species described are
   Tropidelasma yamasugensis and Cleiothyridina hayasakai. The Yamasuge
   fauna is a correlative of the Nabeyama fauna from the Middle Permian of
   Nabeyama in the Kuzu area. There is a strong affinity between the
   Yamasuge fauna and the Middle Permian North American (West Texas) fauna.
C1 Tazawa, Jun-ichi; Department of Geology, Faculty of Science, Niigata
   University, Niigata 950-2181, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1349-1237

   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

   Mountains, Kuzu area, Yamasuge / ] [Permian / Middle Permian / ]. 
   Cleiothyridina hayasakai; Tropidelasma yamasugensis [Japan /  / new
   species] [Permian /  / ].

DT Article
TI A Lower Permian mixed Boreal-Tethyan brachiopod fauna from the
   Nagaiwa-Sakamotozawa area, South Kitakami Belt, NE Japan.
AU Tazawa, Jun-ichi
   Shintani, Tomohiko
SO Science Reports of Niigata University Geology
VL 25
PS 51-62
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three brachiopod species are described for the first time from the
   lowest part of the Sakamotozawa Formation (Sakmarian) of the Nagaiwa-
   Sakamotozawa area, South Kitakami Belt, northeast Japan. The specimens
   include two Boreal-type species, Waagenoconcha humboldti (d'Orbigny) and
   Rhynchopora sp., and a Tethyan-type species, Scacchinella sp. The
   occurrence of a mixed Boreal-Tethyan brachiopod fauna from the Lower
   Permian of the South Kitakami Belt suggests that the South Kitakami
   region was part of a continental shelf bordering the eastern margin of
   North China (Sino-Korea) during the Early Permian.
C1 Tazawa, Jun-ichi; Department of Geology, Faculty of Science, Niigata
   University, Niigata 950-2181, Japan, Japan.

   Honshu, Iwate, Nagaiwa-Sakamotozawa area / new record; systematics]
   [Permian / Sakmarian / ].

DT Article
TI A new demosponge, Choiaella scotica, from the Caradoc (Ordovician) of
   Wallace's Cast, Southern Uplands.
AU Beresi, Matilde S.
   Botting, Joseph P. (joseph.botting@leeds.gov.uk) 
   Clarkson, Euan
SO Scottish Journal of Geology
VL 46
IS 1
PS 77-83
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Synopsis Two specimens of a new choiid demosponge, Choiaella scotica sp.
   nov., have been identified in the collections of the National Museums of
   Scotland. This is one of very few post-Cambrian records for the family,
   and only the second from Scotland. Both Scottish records occur in fine
   sandstones of shallow-water origin, but in probably different
   depositional environments, with the new specimens being transported into
   deeper water. It is possible that this group was abundant and widespread
   in shallow-water siliciclastic environments during the Early Palaeozoic,
   but its record has been limited by the low preservation potential of
   these habitats. The taxonomy of Choiidae is discussed, with the emphasis
   on establishing potentially useful diagnostic features for future
   discoveries.
C1 Botting, Joseph P.; Leeds Museum Discovery Centre, Carlisle Road,
   Hunslet, Leeds, LS10 1LB, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM joseph.botting@leeds.gov.uk
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0036-9276
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; United Kingdom; Geological time periods;
   Palaeozoic
DE Choiaella scotica [Scotland /  / new species] [Ordovician /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Choiaella scotica (Demospongiae): [Sp nov, Scotland, Ordovician, P. 79;
   Fossil].

   Fossil].

DT Article
TI A review of the Carboniferous fossil insects from Scotland.
AU Ross, A.J. (a.ross@nms.ac.uk) 
SO Scottish Journal of Geology
VL 46
IS 2
PS 157-168
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB The known fossil insects of Carboniferous age from Scotland are
   reviewed. Of the seven recorded, one record is highly dubious and
   rejected, and another is herein identified as a crustacean. The
   remaining five insects belong to three orders: The extinct order
   Protodonata (giant dragonflies) is represented by the holotype of
   Truemania multiplicata (Bolton 1922). The extinct order
   Palaeodictyoptera is represented by the holotypes of Lithomantis
   carbonarius Woodward 1876 and the nymph Idoptilus peachii (Woodward
   1887b) comb. nov. The order Blattodea (cockroaches) is represented by
   the lost holotype of 'Lithomylacris' kirkbyi Woodward 1887a and a nearly
   complete cockroach, herein identified as Archimylacris? sp. The
   localities and ages are reviewed and the five insect specimens came from
   the Coal Measures (Westphalian) of Ayrshire and Fife.
C1 Ross, A.J.; Department of Natural Sciences, National Museums Collection
   Centre, National Museums Scotland, 242 West Granton Road, Edinburgh, EH5
   1JA, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM a.ross@nms.ac.uk
SC Zoology
SN 0036-9276

   Kingdom; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

TI Taxonomic study of subgenus Servillia Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera,
   Tachinidae) from North China.
AU Chi, Yu
   Hao, Jing
   Zhang, Chun-tian
SO Shenyang Shifan Daxue Xuebao Ziran Kexue Ban
VL 28
IS 1
SU Sum No 87
PS 86-89
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this study, 290 specimens of the subgenus Servillia Robineau-Desvoidy
   of Tachina ( Diptera, Tachinidae) collected from 15 provinces,
   municipalities and autonomous regions of North China in the Insect
   Collection of Shenyang Normal University (SNU, Shenyang), China
   Agricultural University (CAU, Beijing), Beijing Forestry University
   (BFU, Beijing) and General Station of Forest Pest Management, the State
   Forestry Administration of China (GSFPM, Shenyang) were examined and
   classified, and 16 species of Servillia were recognized, viz. T. (S.)
   amurensis, T. (S.) anguisipennis (endemic), T. (S.) ardens, T. (S.)
   bombylia, T. (S.) breviceps, T. (S.) cheni (endemic), T. (S.) iota, T.
   (S.) jakovlewii, T. (S.) laterolinea, T. (S.) lateromaculata, T. (S.)
   luteola, T. (S.) stackelbergi, T. (S.) ursina, T. (S.) ursinoidea, T.
   (S.) zimini and T. (S.) sp., and new provincial distribution locations
   of 10 species was provided.

TI Study on the Genus Hebecnema (Diptera: Muscidae) with Description of A
   New Species from Sichuan, China.
AU Wang, Yan-xia (Yaanbmshw@sina.com) 
   Feng, Yan
SO Sichuan Journal of Zoology
VL 29
IS 4
PS 566-568
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Unpaginated plate.
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Hebecnema Schnabl, 1889 belongs to Mydaeini, Mydaeinae of
   Muscidae. About 23 species are known in the world, 10 species (including
   a new species) have been found in China. Among them, 5 species are
   distributed in Sichuan Province, of which 4 species are endemic. In this
   paper, a key to 5 known species of Hebecnema in Sichuan is given, and
   one new species, Hebecnema coronata Feng et Wang, sp. nov., is described
   and illustrated. The type specimen is deposited in the Entomological
   Museum, Shanghai Institute of Plant Physiology & Ecology, Chinese
   Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, China. Hebecnema coronata Feng et Wang,
   sp.nov. (Figs. 1-3) Male: Body length 5.0 mm, wings 5.0 mm, dark black.
   This new species is similar to Hebecnema invisifacies Feng, 2009, but
   differs from the latter in that the eyes are sparsely covered with
   microchaeta, but the latter one is densely covered with cilia; arista
   short plumose, the longest hair on the arista is about 0.13 times the
   width of 3rd antennal segment, but the latter is long plumose, the
   longest hair is as long as the width of 3rd one; lst sternite hairy, but
   the latter one bare; lateral lobi of the 5th sternite outward extends
   respectively, but the latter one contracts inward; surstyli longer than
   the cerci in the lateral view, but the latter is shorter than one
   distinctly. Female: Unknown. Holotype [male], Mingshan (Cheling,
   30[degree]04[minute] N, 103[degree]14[minute] E, alt. 560 m), Sichuan
   prov., 27 June 1984, coll. by FENG Yan. Etymology: The specific name was
   derived from Latin words "coron" and "ata", referring to the lobi of 5th
   sternite outward extend as corolliform
C1 Wang, Yan-xia; Yaan Municipal Center for Disease Control and Prevention,
   Yaan, Sichuan Province 625000, China, China.
EM Yaanbmshw@sina.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7083
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   Hebecnema coronata [Sichuan /  / New species].

   Muscidae

   567].

DT Article
TI Study on the Taxonomy of the Genus Gessius Distant (Hemiptera:
   Cicadellidae: Iassinae) from China.
AU Li, Jian-da
   Li, Zi-zhong (lizizhong38@163.com) 
SO Sichuan Journal of Zoology
VL 29
IS 4
PS 569-572, 575
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Article continued on pp. 575.
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present paper, seven species (including a new species) of the
   genus Gessius are recognized from China. A new species G. dentatus sp.
   nov. is described and illustrated. A key to seven Chinese species are
   given. A generic new synonym Parakrisna Cai et He is proposed. Also a
   specific synonym is proposed. The type specimen of the new species is
   kept in the Institute of Entomology, Guizhou University. Gessius
   dentatus sp. nov. (Figs.1-8) Body length (incl. tegm.) : [male]9.8 mm,
   [female]:11.0 mm. This new species resembles G. rufidorsus Wang et Li,
   but can be distinguished by the male aedeagus with a much longer and
   narrower preatrium, the distance from the gonopore to the end of the
   aedeagus is one-quarter as long as the length of aedeagus, apex of
   subgenital plate straight, ventral process with toothed ventral margin,
   its apex straight. Holotype:[male], Guizhou Province: Maolan, 25-V-1998,
   coll. Wang Lian-min. Paratypes: [female], Guizhou Province: Maolan,
   23-X-1998, coll. Li Zi-zhong.
C1 Li, Zi-zhong; Institute of Entomology, Guizhou University, Guiyang
   550025, China, China.

TI A new species of the genus Polyamia (Hemiptera, Cicadellidae,
   Deltocephalinae) from China.
AU Dai, Ren-huai (agr.rhdai@gzu.edu.cn) 
   Xing, Ji-chun
   Li, Zi-zhong
SO Sichuan Journal of Zoology
VL 29
IS 5
PS 570-571
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper, a new species of the genus Polyamia DeLong, Polyamia
   acicularissp. nov. is described from China. Type specimens are deposited
   in the Institute of Entomology, Guizhou University, Guiyang, China.
   Polyamia acicularis sp. nov. (Fig.1) The new species is similar to
   Polyamia penistenuis Zhang et Duan, but it can be distinguished from the
   latter in having the aedeagus shaft long and narrow apically,
   needle-like, with the gonopore apical; style apical curved slender and
   arm long. Length of body (including tegmen) [male]3.9 mm. Holotype
   [male], Jiangxi Jiulianshan (114.28[degree]E, 24.33[degree]N, altitude
   600 m), 19-VII-2008, collected by MENG Ze-hong. Etymology: From
   "acicular-" (Latin for "needle"), the specific epithet refers to the
   aedeagus shaft being needle-like.
C1 Dai, Ren-huai; Institute of Entomology, Guizhou University, Guiyang
   550025, China, China.

AB 176 midges belonging to genera Alluaudomyia, Culicoides, Dasyhelea,
   Forcopomyia, and Stilobezzia, were collected from the Jinggangshan area,
   Jiangxi in October 2009. A new species, namely Stilobezzia jinggangshana
   Yu, Liu & Ma sp. nov., is described and illustrated. Type specimens of
   the new species are deposited in the Collection Gallery of Medical
   Entomology, Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology, Academy of
   Military Medical Sciences (No. 20 Dongdajie Street, Fengtai District,
   Beijing 10071).

PT J

DT Article
TI A Review of African Blastobasinae (Lepidoptera: Gelechioidea:
   Coleophoridae), with New Taxa Reared from Native Fruits in Kenya.
AU Adamski, David (adamskid@si.edu) 
   Copeland, Robert S.
   Miller, Scott E.
   Darrow, Karolyn
   Hebert, Paul D.N.
   Luke, Quentin
SO Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology
VL 630
PS i-vi, 1-68
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Twenty-five species of African Blastobasinae (Lepidoptera:
   Coleophoridae) are reviewed; 12 species are redescribed, and 13 species
   are described as new. Rearing of Lepidoptera ancillary to sampling
   efforts targeted for fruit flies (Diptera: Tephritidae) and their
   parasitoids was conducted in and near forested areas in coastal, central
   highland, and western highland habitats in Kenya. Reared moths were
   associated with fruits of 64 plant species in 34 families. Two new
   species, Blastobasis millicentae and Neoblastobasis perisella, were
   discovered in mixed original type series of species described by Meyrick
   and also reared from fruit. Eight new species, Blastobasis acirfa, B.
   aynekiella, B. chuka, B. elgonae, B. kenya, B. glauconotata, and
   Neoblastobasis ximeniaella, and N. wangithiae, are known only from
   specimens reared from fruit. One new species, Blastobasis catappaella,
   was reared from fruit and collected at black light. Finally, two new
   species, Neoblastobasis laikipiae and Blastobasis mpala, are known only
   from black light samples. DNA barcodes augmented the ability to
   discriminate between some closely related species within several genera.
   Male specimens of Blastobasis kenya, B. acirfa, and B. aynekiella and
   some associated female conspecifics, in particular, had distinctly
   different barcodes but were not initially diagnosed using standard
   morphological features. Subsequently, corroborative morphological
   features were found to support the DNA barcode data, and both data are
   discussed herein. Lectotypes are designated for Blastobasis arguta
   Meyrick, 1918; B. byrsodepta Meyrick, 1913; B. egens Meyrick, 1918; B.
   eridryas Meyrick, 1932; B. extensa Meyrick, 1918; B. indigesta Meyrick,
   1931; B. industria Meyrick, 1913; and B. trachilista Meyrick, 1921.
   Zenodochium arguta Meyrick, 1918 is transferred to Calosima Dietz, 1910,
   new combination, and Tecmerium irroratella Walsingham, 1891 and
   Blastobasis extensa Meyrick, 1918 are transferred to Holcocera Clemens,
   1863, new combinations. Neoblastobasis indigesta (Meyrick, 1931),
   revised status, is transferred to Blastobasis Zeller, 1855. Syndroma
   Meyrick is a junior synonym of Holcocera Clemens, 1863, and Syndroma
   lignyodes Meyrick, 1914 is transferred to Holcocera, new combination.
   The first African records for Holcocera, Calosima, and Neoblastobasis
   are reported. A key for all African Blastobasinae is included, together
   with photographs of the adults and illustrations of the male and female
   genitalia. Distribution maps are provided for all new species reared
   from fruits. All taxonomic decisions such as new species, lectotype
   designations, synonymies, and transfers are attributed to the senior
   author.
C1 Adamski, David; Smithsonian Inst, Dept Entomol, POB 37012,NHB E523,
   Washington, DC, USA, USA.
EM adamskid@si.edu
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 0081-0282
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Nutrition;
   Diet; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Blastobasinae [Food plants /  / Systematics] [Africa /  / Key to
   species] [ /  / distribution]. 
   Blastobasis acirfa; Blastobasis aynekiella; Blastobasis catappaella;
   Blastobasis chuka; Blastobasis elgonae; Blastobasis glauconotata;
   Blastobasis kenya; Blastobasis mpala; Neoblastobasis laikipiae;
   Neoblastobasis wangithiae; Neoblastobasis ximeniaella [Kenya /  / New
   species]. 
   Blastobasis millicentae [Kenya /  / New species] [South Africa /  / ]. 
   Neoblastobasis perisella [Congo-Kinshasa /  / New species] [Kenya /  /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Gelechioidea, Blastobasidae

   P. 23].

   designated, P. 39; Redescription, P. 39]. 
   Blastobasis catappaella - Adamski 2010 (Blastobasidae): [Sp nov, Kenya,

   [Redescription, P. 8; Comb nov, Transferred from Blastobasis, p. 7].

   Neoblastobasis indigesta - (Meyrick 1931) (Blastobasidae): [Referred to,
   Blastobasis, p. 33].

   P. 9]. 
   Neoblastobasis perisella - Adamski 2010 (Blastobasidae): [Sp nov,
   Congo-Kinshasa, P. 11]. 
   Neoblastobasis wangithiae - Adamski 2010 (Blastobasidae): [Sp nov,
   Kenya, P. 11]. 
   Neoblastobasis ximeniaella - Adamski 2010 (Blastobasidae): [Sp nov,
   Kenya, P. 14]. 
   Syndroma lignyodes - Meyrick 1914 (Blastobasidae): [Referred to,
   Holcocera, p. 6].

   Calosima, p. 8].

DT Article
TI Two new species of snow fly Chionea from Italian Alps (Diptera:
   Limoniidae).
AU Vanin, Stefano (stefano.vanin@unipd.it) 
SO Societa Veneziana di Scienze Naturali Lavori
VL 35
PS 5-14
PD Gennaio 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The snow crane flies belonging to the genus Chionea (Diptera,
   Limoniidae) have a Holarctic distribution, with 17 Palaearctic and 18
   Neartic species. In this paper two new species of snow flies, Chionea
   olympiae and Chionea dolomitana, are described from specimens collected
   in the Alps. The description of C. olympiae is based on males from
   northwestern Italy, collected in a mountainous area belonging to the
   ercinic massif of Mount Rosa. The description of the second species, C.
   dolomitana, is based on specimens from northeastern Italy, collected in
   the Dolomites and Venetian Pre-Alps in an altitudinal range between 1000
   and 2500 m. Chionea araneoides previously thought to occur throughout
   the Alps, seems not to occur in the southeastern Alps.
C1 Vanin, Stefano; Dipartimento di Biologia, Via U. Bassi 58/b, 35100
   Padova, Italy, Italy.
EM stefano.vanin@unipd.it
SC Zoology
SN 0392-9450
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Chionea (Chionea) araneoides [Europe / Alps, south east / Discussion of
   occurrence]. 
   Chionea (Chionea) dolomitana; Chionea (Chionea) olympiae [Italy /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Limoniidae
OR Chionea (Chionea) - Dalman 1816 (Limoniidae): [Key to species, Males, p.
   11]. 
   Chionea (Chionea) araneoides (Limoniidae). 
   Chionea (Chionea) dolomitana (Limoniidae): [Sp nov, Italy, P. 7]. 
   Chionea (Chionea) olympiae (Limoniidae): [Sp nov, Italy, P. 6].

TI Aleocharinae from Madagascar gathered by Guillaume de Rougemont
   (Coleoptera Staphylinidae).
AU Pace, Roberto (pace.ent@tiscali.it) 
SO Societa Veneziana di Scienze Naturali Lavori

PS 15-30

LA English
U1 0

AB In the present study 42 species are treated, belonging 11 tribes
   (Leucocraspedini, Pronomaeini, Gyrophaenini, Placusini, Homalotini,
   Falagriini, Athetini, Lomechusini, Thamiaraeini, Hoplandriini,
   Aleocharini), 23 genera (Leucocraspedum, Nopromaea, Tomoxelia,
   Gyrophaena, Placusa, Homalota, Coenonica, Neosilusa, Anebolura,
   Falagria, Anaulocaspis, Ischnopoda, Lemuridota, Nehemitropia,
   Alomacrotona, Atheta, Pseudacrotona, Madecazyras, Ankaratraella,
   Exaeretota, Ditropandria, Palaeochara, Aleochara). Of these species, 12
   are described as new to science (Tomoxelia lecoqi n. sp., Gyrophaena
   (Gyrophaena) rougemontiana n. sp., Placusa rugosa n. sp., Coenonica
   merina n. sp., Anebolura rougemonti n. sp., Falagria (Myrmecocephalus)
   madafulva n. sp., Alomacrotona rougemonti n. sp., Pseudacrotona
   triangulum n. sp., Pseudacrotona rougemonti n. sp., Ankaratraella
   rougemonti n. sp., Ditropandria rougemonti n. sp., Aleochara (Xenochara)
   madirigaster n. sp.). Melagria isolaensis Pace, 1999 is transferred to
   Anaulacaspis, as A. isaloensis (Pace, 1999) comb. n.

DT Article
TI Eight new species and three newly recorded species of the ant genus
   Temnothorax Mayr (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from the Chinese mainland,
   with a key.
AU Zhou, Shanyi (syzhou@mailbox.gxnu.edu.cn) 
   Huang, Jianhua
   Yu, Daojian
   Liu, Zhongjian
SO Sociobiology
VL 56
IS 1
PS 7-26
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Eight new species of the ant genus Temnothorax Mayr are described, i.e.
   T. angulohumerus sp. nov., T. orchidus sp. nov., T. maoerensis sp.nov.,
   T. striatus sp. nov., T. ruginosus sp.nov., T. shannxiensis sp. nov., T.
   zhejiangensis sp. nov. and T. leyeensis sp. nov. Three previously
   described species are newly recorded from China, i.e. T. koreanus
   (Teranishi), T. pisarskii Radchenko, and T. mongolicus (Pisarski). A key
   to the known species of Temnothorax from the Chinese mainland is
   provided, based on the worker caste.
C1 Zhou, Shanyi; College of Life Sciences, Guangxi Normal University,
   Guilin 541004, China, China.
EM syzhou@mailbox.gxnu.edu.cn

DT Article
TI Contributions to the knowledge of the myrmecophilous pselaphines
   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Pselaphinae) from China. IV. The second
   species of the genus Songius (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Pselaphinae),
   with descriptions of its probable mature larva.
AU Zhao, Mei-Jun (mjzhao@shnu.edu.cn) 
   Yin, Zi-Wei
   Li, Li-Zhen
SO Sociobiology
VL 56
IS 1
PS 77-89
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The second species of the myrmecophilous genus Songius Yin et Li, 2009,
   S. hlavaci sp. nov., is described and illustrated on the basis of adult
   male and probable larval specimens collected from Tianmushan Mountain,
   Zhejiang Province, East China. Both the adult and larva occur in nests
   of the ant Lasius (Lasius) niger (Linnaeus, 1758). A key to the species
   of Songius is given. The systematic position of the species is
   discussed.

   Guilin Road, Shanghai, 200234, China, China.

PT J
AN ZOOR14701003921
DT Article
TI Newly recognised sibling species of Rhynchomicropteron nudiventer
   (Diptera: Phoridae).
AU Disney, R.H.L. (rhld2@hermes.cam.ac.uk) 
SO Sociobiology
VL 56
IS 1
PS 249-253
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Rhynchomicropteron Annandale (1912) has distinctive flightless
   females, which are characterized by narrow wing rudiments and a very
   long proboscis; as well as by their association with ants. The males are
   poorly known, but Brown (1992) reported that the genus Gymnoselia
   Schmitz (1927) represented the missing males, which had been assigned to
   a different subfamily. At present males can only be named by association
   with their females, unless covered by Brown (1992) or Schmitz (1929).
   Eventually it is likely that two Rhynchomicropteron species will be
   found to be the females of the two species of 'Gymnoselia', which were
   described from India and Java. The females of the sixteen species known
   from the Oriental Region were most recently keyed by Disney & Kistner
   (1998) supplemented by Disney (1999). When Brown (1992) reared a species
   in Thailand, and he described the larvae and males, he had sent me a
   female which I attributed to R. nudiventer Papp (1982). The species R.
   nudiventer is keyed out (in Disney & Kistner 1998) in the final couplet,
   largely on the basis of negative characters, such as lack of dorsal hair
   palisades on the hind tibiae and the lack of abdominal tergites. With
   the accumulation of further specimens in the University of Cambridge
   Museum of Zoology (UCMZ) attributed to this species it has become
   apparent that the females of R. nudiventer are somewhat variable in
   addition to their variation in size. However, the species described
   below is now proposed as being a distinct sibling species of R.
   nudiventer.
C1 Disney, R.H.L.; Department of Zoology, University of Cambridge, Downing
   Street, Cambridge CB2 3EJ, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM rhld2@hermes.cam.ac.uk
SC Zoology
SN 0361-6525
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Rhynchomicropteron laticosta [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Phoridae
OR Rhynchomicropteron laticosta (Phoridae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 249]. 
   Rhynchomicropteron nudiventer - Papp 1982 (Phoridae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 250; Description, Female & putative males, p. 251]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14701003921
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14702010847
DT Article
TI Genetic Relationship Between Coptotermes heimi and Coptotermes gestroi
   (Isoptera: Rhinotermitidae).
AU Yeap, Beng-Keok (chowyang@usm.my) 
   Dugal, Farkhanda Manzoor
   Othman, Ahmad Sofiman
   Lee, Chow-Yang
SO Sociobiology
VL 56
IS 2
PS 291-312
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Coptotermes heimi (Wasmann) is a destructive subterranean termite
   species commonly found on the Indian subcontinent. Using partial
   sequences of the mitochondrial genes rRNA small subunit 12S, rRNA large
   subunit 16S and cytochrome oxidase subunit 2 (COII), together with
   morphometric measurements, we determined the relationship between C.
   heimi and Coptotermes gestroi (Wasmann). Gene sequences obtained from 13
   populations of C. heimi from Pakistan and one population of C. gestroi
   from Malaysia, along with other sequences of C. heimi, C. gestroi,
   Coptotermes formosanus Shiraki and other Coptotermes spp. from GenBank,
   were used in the analysis. Seventeen morphometric measurements of C.
   gestroi and C. heimi revealed numerous overlaps. The morphological
   analysis using Principle Component Analysis (PGA) and Discriminant
   Function Analysis (D FA) failed to differentiate C. heimi from C.
   gestroi. Individuals from both species were clustered together in the
   scatter plots. Phylogenetic analysis of 12S, 16S, and COII gene
   sequences suggested that both species are likely conspecific. Based on
   the molecular phylogenetics and morphometric data, we propose that C.
   heimi is a junior synonym of C. gestroi.
C1 Yeap, Beng-Keok; Univ Sains Malaysia, Sch Biol Sci, Penang, Malaysia,
   Malaysia.
EM chowyang@usm.my
RI Lee, Chow-Yang/C-7129-2009
OI Lee, Chow-Yang/0000-0001-8279-4104; Othman, Ahmad
   Sofiman/0000-0002-4944-4177
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0361-6525
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Genetics; Evolution; Variation;
   Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Coptotermes gestroi; Coptotermes heimi [Molecular genetics /
   Mitochondrial rRNA 12S & 16S & COII sequence diversity / taxonomic
   implications] [Phylogeny / Morphological & molecular phylogenetic
   analysis / ] [Biochemical variation /  / ] [Malaysia /  / ] [Pakistan / 
   / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Isoptera
OR Coptotermes gestroi - (Wasmann 1896) (Isoptera): [Syn nov, Coptotermes
   heimi (Wasmann 1902), p. 308]. 
   Coptotermes heimi - (Wasmann 1902) (Isoptera). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14702010847
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI New Species and New Records of Scuttle Flies (Diptera: Phoridae)
   Associated with Neotropical Army Ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae).
AU Disney, R.H.L. (rhld@hermes.cam.ac.uk) 
   Rettenmeyer, C.W.
SO Sociobiology
VL 55
IS 1 A
PS 7-83
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The following new myrmecophile species are described: Acontistoptera
   longiseta Disney sp. n., A. medisetosa Disney sp. n., Apterophora
   chadabae Disney sp. n., Holopterina tenuipalpis Disney sp. n., Megaselia
   osapenensis Disney sp. n., Puliciphora fuschermanni Disney sp. n P.
   hermanni Disney sp. n., Thalloptera confusa Disney sp. n., T intermedia
   Disney sp. n., T. robusta Disney sp. n., Xanionotum longbotellus Disney
   sp. n., and X. pilosusphilum Disney sp. n. A key to the females of four
   species of Apterophora is provided. It includes two that arc given code
   letters only until they arc linked to their males. Ecitophora
   luteipalpis Schmitz is synonymised with E. parva Schmitz. Ecitoptera
   subciliata Borgmeier is synonymised with E. humeralis Borgmeier. Revised
   keys to the females of Ecitoptera, of Thalloptera and of the Xanionotum
   hystrix species group are provided. A series of males whose genera
   cannot be confirmed until they are linked to their females are given
   code letters and briefly characterized. The parasitoid species
   Pseudacteon carli Disney sp. n. and P. microbrowni Disney sp. n. are
   described.

DT Article
TI New Species and New Records of Apocephalus Coquillett (Diptera:
   Phoridae) that Parasitize Ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in America.
AU Brown, Brian V. (bbrown@nhm.org) 
   Disney, R. Henry L.
   Elizalde, Luciana
   Folgarait, Patricia J.
SO Sociobiology
VL 55
IS 1 B
PS 165-190
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The following new species of Apocephalus ant-parasitizing flies are
   described: Apocephalus exlobicornis Brown & Disney, A. exstriatus Brown
   & Disney, A. flavitenuipes Brown & Disney,A. intermedius Brown &
   Disney,A. longisetarum Brown & Disney, A. necdivergens Brown & Disney,

PT J

DT Article
TI Contributions to the Knowledge of the Myrmecophilous Pselaphines
   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Pselaphinae) from China. III. Two New Genera
   and Two New Species of the Subtribe Batrisina (Staphylinidae,
   Pselaphinae, Batrisitae) from a Colony of Lasius niger (Hymeptera
   [Hymenoptera], Formicidae, Formicinae) in East China.
AU Yin, Zi-Wei
   Li, Li-Zhen
   Zhao, Mei-Jun (lizhenli@shnu.edu.cn) 
SO Sociobiology
VL 55
IS 1 B
PS 241-253
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Two new genera and two new species of subtribe Batrisina, viz., Songius
   lasiuohospes gen. et sp. nov. and Sinotrisus nomurai gen. et sp. nov.,
   from Zhejiang Province, East China are described and illustrated. Both
   genera were collected from a colony of Lasius (Lasius) niger (Linnaeus,
   1758) and belong to the Tribasodes genus-group (defined by Nomura &
   Idris, 2003) by reason of having the metatrochanter with a denticle or a
   protuberance on the posterior margin in the male and totally
   asymmetrical aedeagus with an uncomplete dorsal apophysis. Systematic
   positions of the new genera are discussed. A key to the myrmecophilous
   genera of subtribe Batrisina known from China is provided.
C1 Zhao, Mei-Jun; Shanghai Normal Univ, Dept Biol, 100 Guilin Rd, Shanghai,
   China, China.
EM lizhenli@shnu.edu.cn
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0361-6525

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   genera] [China /  / Key to genera; associated with Formicidae
   (Hymenoptera)].

   genera] [China /  / Key to associated Coleoptera].

   New associate species] [ / Songius lasiuohospes (Coleoptera) / ]

   Sinotrisus nomurai; Songius lasiuohospes [Associations / Lasius (Lasius)
   niger (Hymenoptera) / New associate species] [Zhejiang /  / New species;
   hymenopteran associate].

   Pselaphidae, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata, Formicoidea, Formicidae

   Formicidae (Hymenoptera), males, p. 243].

TI A New Species of the Ant Genus Lasiomyrma (Hymenoptera, Formicidae,

AB A new species of the genus Lasiomyrma is described from Thailand under
   the name, L. wiwatwitayai Jaitrong, sp. nov., based on the worker caste.
   This species probably constructs its nests in rotten wood on the forest
   floor.

DT Article
TI Revision of the Genus Falagonia (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae:
   Aleocharinae: Lomechusini), With Description of Related Genera.
AU Santiago-Jimenez, Quiyari J. (quiyari@hotmail.com) 
SO Sociobiology
VL 55
IS 3
PS 643-723
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB I present the redescription of the genus Falagonia based on new field
   specimens and the review of museum series. Falagonia is proposed as a
   monotypic genus, including only to F. mexicana Sharp, 1883. The former
   Falagonia crassiventris Sharp, 1883 is placed under Pseudofalagonia new
   genus. Six new genera and ten new species closely related to Falagonia
   are described. Lectotype and paralectotype are designated here for F.
   mexicana Sharp, 1883. Also, a lectotype is designated for
   Pseudofalagonia crassiventris (Sharp), 1883 new combination. Keys to the
   genera and their species are provided. Illustrations of structural and
   genitalic features are provided.
C1 Santiago-Jimenez, Quiyari J.; Inst Ecol AC, Dept Biol Evolut, Km 2-5
   Antigua Carretera,Coatpec 351, Xalapa, Veracruz, Mexico, Mexico.
EM quiyari@hotmail.com

SN 0361-6525

   Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America; South America

PT J

DT Article
TI Feather Mites Associated with Eastern Bluebirds (Sialia sialis L.) in
   Georgia, Including the Description of a New Species of Trouessartia
   (Analgoidea: Trouessartiidae).
AU Carleton, Renee E. (rcarleton@berry.edu) 
   Proctor, Heather C.
SO Southeastern Naturalist
VL 9
IS 3
PS 605-623
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Eastern Bluebirds inhabiting a grass-dominated agricultural environment
   within a northwestern Georgia land tract were examined over the course
   of three breeding seasons (2004 through 2006) to assess the presence of
   ectosymbionts. More than 90% of bluebirds examined harbored plumicolous
   feather mites of four species: Pterodectes sialiarum
   (Proctophyllodidae), Mesalgoides sp. (Psoroptoididae), Analges sp.
   (Analgidae), and a previously undescribed Trouessartia sp. The recovery
   of P. sialiarum represented the second report of this species, which had
   previously been recorded from Eastern Bluebirds in Guatemala. New host
   records for Mesalgoides sp. and Analges sp., and a description of
   Trouessartia sialiae sp. nov. also resulted from the study. Mite
   abundance did not vary among groups of birds categorized by subjective
   quantifi cation, with the exception of a group of a few individuals
   harboring a vast number of mites. Abundance was not correlated with mean
   host body mass or body condition and was also independent of host sex.
   Feather mites were most commonly found on primary remiges, occasionally
   on secondary remiges, and rarely on rectrices; each mite species was
   located on a specifi c type of feather. Lice were also occasionally
   recovered, but were reported separately.
C1 Carleton, Renee E.; Department of Biology, School of Mathematical and
   Natural Sciences, Berry College, 2277 Martha Berry Highway NW, Mount
   Berry, GA 30149, USA, USA.
EM rcarleton@berry.edu
RI Proctor, Heather C./A-2677-2014
OI Proctor, Heather C./0000-0002-4920-9556
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1528-7092
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA

PT J
AN ZOOR14610066531
DT Article
TI Canacidae and Australimyzidae (Diptera) collected by Danish Scientific
   Expeditions and by N.L.H. Krauss, with descriptions of four new species.
AU Munari, Lorenzo (lormun@iol.it) 
SO Steenstrupia
VL 32
IS 1
PS 51-68
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Four new species of the beach fly family Canacidae are described, and
   some new records of both canacid and australimyzid flies from the field
   collections carried out by Danish Scientific Expeditions and by the
   entomologist N.L.H. Krauss are given. Nocticanace kraussi sp. nov.,
   Masoniella darwini sp. nov., Pelomyia fuegina sp. nov. and
   Dasyrhicnoessa celata sp. nov. are described from the Cook Islands
   (Polynesia), southern Patagonia, Tierra del Fuego, and the Bismarck
   Islands, respectively. Two other possibly new species, each represented
   by a single female, are briefly described and discussed but not named
   herein. Updated keys to the species of Masoniella Vockeroth and of the
   melanocera-group of Pelomyia Williston are also provided.
C1 Munari, Lorenzo; Nat Hist Museum, Entomol Sect, S Croce 1730, Venice,
   Italy, Italy.

PT J
AN ZOOR14709063784
DT Article
TI Decapod crustaceans from the Middle Eocene (Bartonian) of Soave (Verona
   - NE Italy).
FT Crostacei decapodi dell'Eocene Medio (Bartoniano) di Soave (Verona -
   Italia nordorientale).
AU Beschin, Claudio (comune@comune.montecchio-maggiore.vi.it) 
   Busulini, Alessandra
   Tessier, Giuliano
SO Studi e Ricerche Associazione Amici Museo Civico "G. Zannato" Montecchio
   Maggiore (VI)
VL 17
PS 11-28
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new decapod fauna has been discovered from the Bartonian levels
   cropping out at Soave (Veronese Lessini). It includes the new anomuran
   Eocalcinus albus sp. nov. (Diogenidae Ortmann, 1892) and 15 forms of
   brachyurans belonging to Lophoranina Fabiani. 1910. Ranilia H.
   Milne-Edwards, 1837, Raninoides H. Milne Edwards, 1837 (Raninidae De
   Haan, 1839), Calappilia A. Milne Edwards, 1873 (Calappidae De Haan,
   1833), Lobonotus A. Milne Edwards, 1863, Titanocarcinus A. Milne
   Edwards, 1863 (Tumidocarcinidae Schweitzer, 2005), Harpactoxanthopsis
   Via Boada, 1959 (Zanthopsidae Via Boada. 1959). Magvarcarcinus
   Schweitzer & Karasawa, 2004 (Goneplacidae MacLeay, 1838), Periacanthus
   Bittner, 1875 (Epialtidae MacLeay, 1838), Micromaia Bittner, 1875, and
   Mithracia Bell, 1858 (Majidae Samouelle, 1819) with Mithracia soavensis
   sp. nov. The fauna has an intermediate age between the well known
   Lutetian ones from the Alpone-Agno graben (Eastern Lessini - NE Italy)
   and the Priabonian ones from Hungary and shows evident affinities with
   both. Not so clear are the relationships with the late Eocene fauna of
   Venetia. Lophoranina marestiana avesana Bittner, 1884, is probably an
   endemism of the Western Lessini (Verona). The systematic position of
   Titanocarcinus euglyphos Bittner, 1875 within the genus is discussed and
   confirmed.
C1 Beschin, Claudio; Museo Civico "G. Zannato", Piazza Marconi 15, 36075
   Montecchio Maggiore (Vicenza), Italy, Italy.
EM comune@comune.montecchio-maggiore.vi.it
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1127-3100
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Ecology; Zoogeography;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Decapoda [Fossil assemblages /  / systematics] [Zoogeography / Faunal
   affinities & endemism / ] [Italy / Verona / stratigraphical
   distribution] [Eocene / Bartonian / ]. 
   Eocalcinus albus; Mithracia soavensis [Italy /  / new species] [Eocene /
    / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Anomura, Brachyura

   Eocalcinus albus (Anomura): [Sp nov, Italy, Eocene, P. 14; Fossil]. 
   Mithracia soavensis (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Italy, Eocene, P. 24; Fossil].
   
   Titanocarcinus euglyphos - Bittner 1875 (Brachyura): [Taxonomic
   position, P. 22; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Lovaracarcinus granulatus gen. nov., sp. nov., a new brachyuran from the
   Eocene of Chiampo Valley (Vicenza - NE Italia [Italy]).
FT Lovaracarcinus granulatus gen. nov., sp. nov., nuovo brachiuro Eocenico
   della valle del Chiampo (Vicenza - Italia settentrionale).
AU de Angeli, Antonio (antonio.deangeli@alice.it) 
   Beschin, Claudio
SO Studi e Ricerche Associazione Amici Museo Civico "G. Zannato" Montecchio
   Maggiore (VI)
VL 17
PS 29-34
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Lovaracarcinus granulatus gen. nov., sp. nov. (Crustacea, Brachyura,
   Carpiliidae) from the middle Eocene (lower Lutetian) of "Lovara" quarry
   of Chiampo (Monti Lessini orientali, Vicenza, NE Italy) is described.
   The new genus has the carapace with regions not defi ned, front and
   orbits similar to the other known carpiliids. However, it is distinct
   for the lateral margins with six lobes (excluded the postorbital spine),
   four on the anterior margin and two on the posterior margin. The family
   Carpiliidae was known in the Tertiary of Veneto with six species
   belonging to Carpilius, Palaeocarpilius and Paraocalina.
C1 de Angeli, Antonio; Piazzetta Nostro Tetto, 9, I - 36100 Vicenza, Italy,
   Italy.
EM antonio.deangeli@alice.it
SC Zoology
SN 1127-3100

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene

   Lovaracarcinus granulatus [Italy /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI The genus Spilogona Schnabl (Diptera: Muscidae) in north European
   Russia: new records and new species.
AU Sorokina, Vera S. (sorokinavs@mail.ru) 
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 16
IS 1-2
PS 29-39
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A list is given of the species of the genus Spilogona Schnabl, 1911
   (Muscidae) of the North European Territory of Russia. 39 species of
   Spilogona are listed, including two new species from the Archangel'skaya
   oblast': Spilogona vikhrevi spec. nov. and Spilogona archangelica spec.
   nov. Spilogona genualis Huckett, 1965 is newly recorded from Russia and
   the Palaearctic region. Spilogona norvegica (Ringdahl, 1932) and
   Spilogona nitidicauda (Schnabl, 1911) are newly recorded from the North
   European Territory of Russia. The male terminalia of the new species are
   figured.

DT Article
TI An enigmatic new genus and species of phorid fly from Baltic amber.
AU Brown, Brian V. (bbrown@nhm.org) 
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 16
IS 1-2
PS 43-46
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and a new species of Phoridae, Jealia pulcherrima gen. et
   spec. nov., is described from Eocene/Oligocene Baltic amber. It is
   highly unusual in having a medial acrostichal row of setae in
   combination with modern phorid wing venation. With its combination of
   primitive and derived characters, its phylogenetic relationships are
   unknown.
C1 Brown, Brian V.; Entomology Section, Natural History Museum of Los
   Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA,
   USA.

DT Article
TI On the Pallopteridae (Diptera) of Tajikistan, with the description of a
   new species.
AU Ozerov, Andrey L. (ozerov2455@rambler.ru) 
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 16
IS 1-2
PS 69-72
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Pallopteridae, Toxoneura shakhdarana spec. nov., is
   described from Tajikistan. The darkening along vein M between crossveins
   r-m and dm-cu is a unique character for this species, distinguishing it
   from all known Palaearctic species of Pallopteridae. The new species is
   similar to Toxoneura alticola Ozerov, 1994, but can also be
   differentiated from it by black hairs on the gena and a short apical
   ventral seta on the mid tibia. A k?? for Tajikistan species of
   Pallopteridae is provided.
C1 Ozerov, Andrey L.; Zoological Museum, Moscow State University, Bol'shaya
   Nikitskaya Street, 6, Moscow 125009, Russia, Russia.
EM ozerov2455@rambler.ru

DT Article
TI Merodon alexandri spec. nov. - a new species of hover-fly (Diptera:
   Syrphidae) from the Northern Black Sea Region.
AU Popov, Grigory V. (mbu@yandex.ru) 
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 16
IS 1-2
PS 133-151
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Merodon alexandri spec. nov. is described from eastern Ukraine and the
   adjacent area of Russia. The new species is similar to M. loewi van der
   Goot, but differs mainly by the shape and size of the spur on hind
   trochanter and the apical spur on hind tibia of the male, and also by
   the male terminalia structure and a somewhat smaller body. Data on the
   ecology of the species are also reported. An updated key to the species
   of the M. ruficornis group of the northern Black Sea region is provided.
C1 Popov, Grigory V.; Donetsk Botanical Gardens, National Academy of
   Sciences of Ukraine, 110 Illich's Avenue, Donetsk 83059, Ukraine,
   Ukraine.
EM mbu@yandex.ru

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

DT Article
TI Syrphoidea (Diptera: Pipunculidae and Syrphidae) previously unrecorded
   from Sardinia (Italy), with the description of a new species of the
   genus Pipunculus Latreille.
AU Kehlmaier, Christian (kehlmaier@web.de) 
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 16
IS 1-2
PS 155-167
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Faunistic data on Syrphoidea new for Sardinia are presented. Among the
   Pipunculidae, Pipunculus tumbarinus spec. nov. is described, illustrated
   and characterised by DNA-barcodes. Five additional taxa represent first
   records for Italy, whereas all 18 identified species are new for
   Sardinia. The male and female terminalia of Cephalops conjunctivus Coe,
   1958, are illustrated. An updated checklist of Italian Pipunculidae is
   presented. In the Syrphidae, ten species are recorded from Sardinia for
   the first time, including one first record for Italy (Riponnensia
   daccordii (Claussen, 1991)).

TI A peculiar new species of Blennidus Motschulsky subgenus Agraphoderus
   Bates from the Andes of the Cordillera Blanca (Peru) (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae: Pterostichini).
AU Allego, Gianni (gianni.allegro@entecra.it) 
SO Studies and Reports of District Museum Prague-East Taxonomical Series
VL 6
IS 1-2
PS 1-7
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Blennidus (Agraphoderus) huascarani sp. nov. is described from the Andes
   of Peru (Dept. Ancash, Cordillera Blanca). Type locality: Quebrada
   Putaca, Punta Olimpica Pass, S 9[degree]08[minute]19[second]/W
   77[degree]30[minute]18[second], 4600 m a.s.l. This species differs from
   the other subgenus Agraphoderus species by its depressed habitus,
   slender legs and the morphology of the aedeagus. Illustrations of the
   habitus, the median lobe of the aedeagus, the right paramere and the
   gonocoxite are shown. The sites where the species was collected are
   illustrated, too. Finally, considerations of the adaptive meaning of
   some peculiar morphological characters as well as of the most likely
   closely related taxa arc reported.
C1 Allego, Gianni; CRA-PLF Unita di Ricerca per le Produzioni legnose Fuori
   Foresta, Strada Frassineto 35, I-15033 Casale Monferrato, (AL), Italy,
   Italy.
EM gianni.allegro@entecra.it
SC Zoology

   South America
